1094631197894836225.text: Legal systems don't stop operating when you find ways to (temporarily) evade their operation. They will continue to be used by your political opponents to make your life and your participation in politics illegal (operationally speaking).

1094631200017108992.text: Political and legal escapism do no fit this bill, and are crappy strategies that we collectively need to abandon asap!

1094631199362826240.text: We have to come up with political strategies that include sensible legal strategies; strategies that use law to defend our way of life.

1094631198599462912.text: We can't shut down legal systems, and we can't afford to abandon law. We have to face that legislatures are subject to capture by powerful interests, and still believe that law exists and is workable.

1094631197274038272.text: I now believe that we need law to secure our existence. We can't do it with technology and extra-legal coordination alone.

1094627313356988418.text: Law is a powerful tool, and there is no sensible reason that we should give up on it because legal systems have been captured and abused. Especially we cannot let *legislatures* dissuade us of the utility of law.

1094626730885636097.text: Now I'm convinced that our collective future depends on our ability to use law for our advantage, as opposed to (as I previously held) on our ability to escape the operation of law

1094625819694063616.text: Now I see that it's more complicated than that. Legal systems can constrain powerful groups, as much as they can empower them. It's actually harder to keep power in check without law than with law.

1094623768457015296.text: Based on a narrow understanding of law, I assumed that legal systems are inherently and inevitably going to be captured and abused by powerful interest groups, and that we can only survive because of extra-legal coordination, because of the limits of legal systems

1094622644752666624.text: I used to think this is a good thing, now I'm convinced it's a bad thing.

1075301018626338817.text: This means that L2 cannot safely clear more value than the cost of disrupting liveness, which is less than the total deposits in L1

1075300424448643072.text: On the other hand, there is a cost that the oligopolists can pay to disrupt the liveness of L1, which means that they can disrupt the safety of L2 for some finite price.

1075300012903596039.text: Otoh the finality of decisions in L1 provides safety against oligopoly. Transaction finality means that L1 can clear orders of magnitude more value than is securing the consensus protocol, because there is no cost that oligopolists can bear to revert finalized blocks.

1075297362967437312.text: But active governance isn't enough to completely mitigate the user safety problems associated with failures in L2 caused by the oligopoly in L1

1061571703808122881.text: The intention is to use changes to the hierarchy to do load balancing and reduce the overhead caused by message routing (which serve cross shard calls and ether transfers). Contracts that call each other more often should be closer together :)

1061570639830618112.text: Message routing inherits the atomicity guarantees one-hop cross-shard message passing. If a block that sends a message is orphaned (with finality), then none of blocks that route that message can be finalized (and will eventually be orphaned if the protocol is live)

1061568292953997312.text: Here's a GIF of a sim of a multi-shard system with cross-shard routing of calls between shards 3 and 6. See https://github.com/cbc-casper/ethshardingpoc …!pic.twitter.com/G3DW4mWSfk

1061191399268323333.text: Here's another GIF of a two-shard system. This one should be considered experimental (has never been implemented without known major bugs). 1061192497555259392.text: These 2 shards "orbit" each other, both having parent blocks (blocks that force blocks that do not synchronize to be orphaned by the fork choice), and both having child blocks!pic.twitter.com/5UtREBefD2

1022154037708259328.text: It's not just that it's legitimate, but that it is a single system that outputs a single result. If it is legitimate, then (because it's monolithic) it will reduce the viability of forking. Which imo is bad because contentious decisions are the most viable opportunity for exit.

1022161165567188993.text: I'm not sure if true, but it definitely would be something! https://twitter.com/soleil_dusoir9/status/1022148605115854853 …

1021957375010332672.text: It's pretty clear, on the other hand, that instituting a single hyper-legitimate voting system along with the norm/mutual expectation that we will all follow the results votes will reduce opportunities for forking. But also the amount of coordination we have to do, to be fair.

1021952158004998144.text: The power of default coordination focal points like voting systems should not be understated. They are incredibly powerful, and incredibly binding. The proposition of adopting the voting system is asking us to tie our collective fates to the result of voting, and to each others'

1021947751162994688.text: will religiously follow the results of the voting system. The result is that everyone's fate is tied to the results of the voting system. In the blockchain space, we aren't inherently in the same boat. In our setting legitimate voting means that there will be fewer chain forks.

1021954000525058049.text: I have a pretty strong preference of politics, signaling and forking over voting as a legitimate coordination mechanism. And these really are mutually exclusive, or at least trade off, because legitimizing the voting system reduces the number of forks that we would expect.
